course_description: Principles, process of speech communication in small group and public speaking situations.
Principles, process of speech communication in small group and public speaking situations.

An introduction to the development and impact of media communications and its technologies on American society. Emphasis on contemporary industry developments, their historical antecedents, as well as contemporary issues related to the influence and impact of media communication on society.
prerequisites: freshman, sophomore or junior standing only

course_description: An introduction to the development and impact of media communications and its technologies on American society. Emphasis on contemporary industry developments, their historical antecedents, as well as contemporary issues related to the influence and impact of media communication on society.
prerequisites: freshman, sophomore or junior standing only. Honors eligibility required

course_description: A hands-on workshop; students will participate in all phases of video production (camera operations, directing, graphics, video replay, and live audio production and digital editing) in a variety of live sports Projects.  There is no requirement of previous production experience or course work.  Course may be repeated an additional two times for credit.  Graded on S/U basis only.
Radio speaking in varied types of programs; console operations, tape editing, microphone techniques.
prerequisites: may be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Topics in Communication - General.
prerequisites: may be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Topics in Communication - Behavioral Science.
prerequisites: may be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Topics in Communication - Humanities/Fine Arts.
prerequisites: may be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: A survey of four main areas of the field communication, interpersonal, organizational, political, and mass communication.
prerequisites: May be restricted to Communications majors through early registration

course_name: Survey of Communication Studies - Writing Intensive
course_description: A survey of four main areas of the field communication, interpersonal, organizational, political, and mass communication.
prerequisites: May be restricted to Communications majors through early registration

course_name: Message Design and Writing for the Media
course_description: This course introduces students to writing for the media in various contexts including television, film and new media (e.g., websites and social media).
prerequisites: COMMUN 2100.   May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: The study and application of techniques applicable to radio, television, and multimedia production with an emphasis on digital audio workstation systems.
prerequisites: COMMUN 2315.   May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Focus on building familiarity with video cameras, microphones, lighting, editing as well as the fundamentals of visual composition, (framing, camera angles, story boards, and  ways to visualize information) and processes and procedures for producing and directing.
prerequisites: sophomore standing.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Focus on advanced production work; more elaborate projects including digital shorts, music videos, and short documentaries; advanced editing, storyboards, and emphasis on developing narrative structure.
prerequisites: COMMUN 3390 or instructor's consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Focuses on writing and administering surveys, conducting field research, and designing experimental studies.
prerequisites: sophomore standing and COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Analysis of form and content of nonverbal communication. Emphasis on role of nonverbal cues in interpersonal communication.
prerequisites: sophomore standing and COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Theory and analysis of communication to promote organizational culture and image.
prerequisites: sophomore standing.  May be restricted to Communication majors during early registration

course_description: (same as ANTHRO 3470, LINGST 3470). Study of the influence of culture on communication processes. Examines topics such as the impact of values, languages, and nonverbal behavior on intercultural interaction.
prerequisites: sophomore standing.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Survey of the theories of mass communication.
prerequisites: COMMUN 2100 or senior standing.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Theory and analysis of communication in conflict situations across a variety of contexts.
prerequisites: sophomore standing required.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Analysis of communication influences on relational identities and development.
prerequisites: sophomore standing and COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (same as ENGLSH 3570 and THEATR 3200). Analysis and oral interpretation of literary works. Graded on A-F basis only.
(same as PEA_ST 3521). Procedures and techniques for interpersonal communication and decision making in small groups.
prerequisites: sophomore standing.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Critical analysis and production of argument emphasizing evidence, reasoning, and refutation.
prerequisites: COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Principles and practice of speech communication in business and professional settings. Emphasis on interviews, group conferences and personal presentations.
prerequisites: sophomore standing and COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: The theory and practice of corporate and political communication responses to crisis situations.
prerequisites: sophomore standing.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Introduction to current issues and trends and relationship among the new technologies, policies, and potential impact on society.
prerequisites: sophomore standing and COMMUN 2100.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent required for repetition.
prerequisites: COMMUN 1200 and COMMUN 2100.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent required for repetition.
prerequisites: junior standing and instructor's consent,  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent required for repetition.
prerequisites: junior standing and instructor's consent.  May be restricted to Communications majors only during early registration

course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.
prerequisites: junior standing and instructor's consent, departmental consent for repetition.  May be restricted to Communications majors only during early registration.  Honors eligibility required

course_description: Application of principles to advanced television production, direction.
prerequisites: COMMUN 3390 and instructor's consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (same as LINGST 4412, ANTHRO 4412; cross-leveled with COMMUN 7412, LINGST 7412, ANTHRO 7412). Relationship among gender, language, nonverbal communication, and culture.
prerequisites: junior standing or departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (same as LINGST 4415; cross-leveled with COMMUN 7415, LINGST 7415). Analysis of the rules of social interaction and the functions of language in discourse.
prerequisites: junior standing and departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (same as PEA_ST 4440; cross-leveled with COMMUN 7440). Exploration and analysis of ethical dimensions intrinsic to human communication.
prerequisites: junior standing or departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 7473). Study of role and impact of communication in political campaigns; historical and contemporary study of influence by communication; case studies and practicum.
prerequisites: junior standing or departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 7474). Studies the persuasive process, attitude formation, modification.
prerequisites: junior standing and COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 7476). Theories of communication systems and processes in organizational structures; study of communication behavior in formal and informal organizational settings.
prerequisites: junior standing and COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 7481).  Development of rhetoric from time of Corax with emphasis on Aristotle; derivation, application of standards for judging effectiveness in communication.
prerequisites: COMMUN 1200, junior standing and departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: (same as H_D_FS 4680; cross-leveled with COMMUN 7520, H_D_FS 7680). Analysis of the functions and processes of communication within families.
prerequisites: junior standing or departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: A general overview of the impact of communication on health, including doctor/patient communication and health campaigns. Graded on A-F basis only.
Development of critical viewing skills including analysis of program conventions, genres, and television aesthetics.
prerequisites: junior standing.  May be restricted to Communication Majors only during early registration

course_description: Focus on social scientific research concerning the mass media in the lives of children and adolescents. The course centers on media effects literature and controversies relevant to child and adolescent media users. Course involves readings, lectures, discussions of theories, concepts, methods, and finding. We will also consider social implication and personal choices in media use. Graded on A-F basis only.
Explores the social implications of new technologies designed for communication. Assumes basic computer knowledge.
prerequisites: junior standing or instructor's consent.  May be restricted to Communication Majors only during early registration

course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent required for repetition.
prerequisites: junior standing and instructor's consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent for repetition.
prerequisites: junior standing and instructor's consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent for repetition.
prerequisites: junior standing and instructor's consent.    May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration

course_description: Directed professional experience within and outside the University in communication-related fields or organizations. Graded on S/U basis only.
prerequisites: Admission to department, junior standing, instructor's consent, 2.5 GPA

course_description: Student contributes to a research project with approved goals and a final written report.  As part of the project, student will read articles in the communication research literature.  Project can be independent or in conjunction with a faculty research project.  Course may be repeated once for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only
prerequisites: COMMUN 3050; junior standing and instructor's consent.  Approval by a faculty member who will serve as project supervisor

course_description: Independent reading, reports.
Integration and adaptation of communication theories to an applied communication problem. Required for all majors.
prerequisites: admission to department, senior standing, and departmental consent

course_description: Integration of theory and practice. The theoretical component of the class is grounded in the study of visual literacy and the practice component will focus on documentary filmmaking. May not be taken by graduate students. It is a capstone course for undergraduate students only.
prerequisites: COMMUN 3390, senior standing;Admission to the department

course_description: Special work for Honors candidates in communication.
Special work for Honors candidates in communication.
Special work for Honors candidates in communication.
(same as LINGST 7412, ANTHRO 7412; cross-leveled with COMMUN 4412, LINGST 4412, ANTHRO 4412). Relationship among gender, language, nonverbal communication, and culture.
(same as LINGST 7415; cross-leveled with COMMUN 4415, LINGST 4415). Analysis of the rules of social interaction and the functions of language in discourse.
(cross-leveled with COMMUN 4400, PEA_ST 4440). Exploration and analysis of ethical dimensions intrinsic to human communication.
(cross-leveled with COMMUN 4473). Study of role and impact of communication in political campaigns; historical and contemporary study of influence by communication; case studies and practicum.
(cross-leveled with COMMUN 4474). Studies the persuasive process, attitude formation, modification.
(cross-leveled with COMMUJN 4476). Theories of communication systems and processes in organizational structures; study of communication behavior in formal and informal organizational settings.
(cross-leveled with COMMUN 4481). Development of rhetoric from time of Corax with emphasis on Aristotle; derivation, application of standards for judging effectiveness in communication.
(same as H_D_FS 7680; cross-leveled with COMMUN 4520, H_D_FS 4680).  Analysis of the functions and processes of communication within families.
A general overview of the impact of communication on health, including doctor/patient communication and health campaigns.  Graded on A-F basis only.
Development of critical viewing skills including analysis of program conventions, genres, and television aesthetics.
Explores the social implications of new technologies designed for communication. Assumes basic computer knowledge.
Study of selected topics in Communication. Topic and credit may vary semester to semester. Repeatable upon consent of department.
Individual study not leading to thesis or dissertation.
Research leading to thesis or dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.

course_name: Introduction to Graduate Study in Communication
course_description: Orientation to the field. Introduction to research methods. Production of research proposal. Emphasizes scholarly style of writing.

course_name: Seminar in Quantitative Methods in Communication
course_description: Quantitative methods of speech research.
Examination of assumptions and techniques of qualitative methods adopting an interpretive framework for analyzing communication phenomena. May be repeated for credit.
Methods of Content Analysis; including consideration of reliability, validity Computer content analysis, codebooks.
Examination and application of various critical methodologies to media texts.
Principles, practice criticism (description, analysis, evaluation) of rhetorical artifacts.

course_name: Seminar in Quantitative Methods in Communication II
course_description: The focus of this course will be the study and practice of various multivariate statistical methods commonly used in communication research. Graded on A-F basis only.
Examines theory and research concerning face-to-face dyadic interactions. Emphasis on context of interpersonal communication events and processes of interactional management.

Exploration of the theoretical foundations of interpersonal communication in the organization, groups and team development, leadership, organizational decision making, motivation and power, bureaucracy, new information technologies, organizational effectiveness and the change process.
Identifies and analyzes theories and variables which explain, predict, and/or influence small group communication.

This course will offer graduate students a broad overview of extant theories employed in the study of mass communication and mass media effects. The class will focus on theories of society, theories of media, and the relationships between mass communication and culture. It will also focus on theories of media structures, media organizations, media content, audiences, and media effects.
Survey of theory and research on political communication; emphasis on messages and audience responses to messages.
Completes comprehensive exams and writes a literature review.
Research leading to thesis or dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.

Student conducts research under close supervision of faculty mentor. Goal: produce research report suitable for submission as convention paper, article, or book chapter. May be repeated once for credit.
prerequisites: consent of mentor required; for advanced graduate students

course_description: Examines the nature of theory, the assumptions underlying theoretical approaches to communication, and surveys themes in contemporary communication theories.

Examines research and theory of family communication; focus on family communication patterns and processes, emphasis on key conceptual, methodological and theoretical aspects of family communication scholarship and research on family forms, processes and outcomes.  Graded on A-F basis only.

The course will review theory and research on topics related to the study of communication and interpersonal relationships. Subjects will rotate and include areas such as relational conflict, gender communication, nonverbal communication, intercultural communication, or interpersonal violence and communication.

Examination of theory and research in selected areas of organizational communication. Topics vary by semester. Topics may include socialization, power, gender, emotions, and others. May be repeated for credit.

Examination of theory and research in selected areas of political communication. Topics vary by semester. Topics may include political polarization, political socialization, politics and the media, political advertising, politics and new media.
Explores current research in the processes and effects of mass communication. Readings pertain to the current social and psychological effects of media on viewers.
Examination of theory and research in selected areas of media communication. Topics vary by semester. May be repeated for credit.

course_name: Seminar in Disaster, Crisis, and Risk
course_description: This course examines several lines of research from multiple disciplines that influence communication during disasters, crises, and emergencies. The course takes a phased approach to disasters, covers Federal government paradigms for disaster communication; crisis communication from an organizational and public relations perspective, risk perception, role of social media and emerging technologies in disasters, media coverage of disasters, and communication and recovery, resilience, and growth.
Theory and research on political campaign debates applied to analyses of candidate debates. Focus on primary and general presidential debates.
Theory and research on political advertising applied to analyses of candidate advertisements. Focus on primary and general presidential television spots and web pages.

course_name: Seminar in Theories of Rhetoric and Criticism
course_description: Directed research on selected topics in rhetorical theory and criticism.
